1092877147541245953.text: Or additionally, "because X graduate students of Y geniuses dedicated their theses to breaking it, and failed". Until then, all of these systems are massive risky experiments, and should be treated as such. Even more so than the public blockchain idea itself.

1092877146652057606.text: And we need much larger bounties on breaking them before we start porting real financial infrastructure. I want to regularly hear a third response to "why is it secure", namely, "because there's been an X bounty on it for Y years", where X and Y are significant.

1092877145930719233.text: We need to glorify trying (and failing!) to break existing systems above simply designing flashy new ones. It's like the replication crisis in a new domain. Let's have whole conferences devoted to trying to break these schemes :)

1092877145209294849.text: I don't know how to solve this problem in the short term. At the very least, we need to make significant additional investments in education and cryptanalysis. We need to radically expand the number of people capable of understanding and auditing these systems.

1092877144525623297.text:

1049662389564727296.text: Like Newtonian dynamics, Bayesian statistics can be a useful tool. But it is fundamentally unfit for a philosophy. You, your beliefs, your decisions, and everyone you interact with deserve better :)

1049662388042178561.text: It replaces real-world reasoning about uncertainty with a mindlessness mechanism, and it is for this that we must be most wary.

1049662386943221760.text: It empowers us to perform criminal acts of inference, such as to deduce distributions from disjunctions, in domains totally independent of invariants like the conservation of energy.

1049662385672339459.text: But this theory has seduced many of us (at times, myself included, but never Vlad!) into misidentifying the entropy of the universe with our own uncertainty about things.

1049662383944273920.text:
It marches most conspicuously under the banner of "Maximum Entropy", 
trumpeting the notion that the universe does not pick favourites among equally energetic states. E.T Jaynes has painted a brilliant and most captivating description of the universe in such terms.

1049662382912524288.text: The fundamental postulate of statistical mechanics is a similar such trick, but we play it on our physics, instead of on our souls, and in that context it seems to work out well, grounded in invariants like the conservation of energy.

1049662381838753792.text:
To believe the Dutch Book is to extinguish all possibility of discovering new things, of self-organization, of emergent phenomena, of the spontaneity of the 
Human spirit and the magic of life.

The Dutch book is a prison for your soul.

1049662379418619904.text: The Dutch book argument is a form of gaslighting. It is the idea that your entire reality consists of simple strategies with well defined pay offs, and that everything you know about the universe adds up perfectly to one.

1049662377900339202.text:
But the Bayesian syndrome isn't a plague of distributions themselves.
It is rather a virus, born of an old Dutch book and the fundamental postulate 
of statistical mechanics.

1049662376692334592.text: There's a few reasons for this. For one, distributions are much more alluring than position and momenta. They seem to assuage the anxieties of dealing with uncertainty all together. And they've had incredible success in the natural sciences, especially the quantum sciences.

1049662375769591809.text: Yet it seems everyone is unflinchingly Bayesian, merrily packaging uncertainty into bouquets that "sum" up nicely and produce steady streams of "expectations". How quaint!

1049662374389669888.text: Of course, no one is seriously Laplacian anymore. Everyone accepts that Quantum reality has shattered the Laplacian dream, and that society's machinery is moving steadily on from its Newtonian basis.

1049662373177516032.text:
In both cases, it is an arrogance born of denial, negligence, misunderstanding 
of the deep embedding of the agent in a non-zero sum universe and of the distinction between the map and the territory.

1049662371927613443.text:
It is an approach predicated on the gumptious assumption of complete information.

For the Laplacian, it was position and momentum of all particles.
For the Bayesian, it's a distribution over all outcomes.

1049662370157645825.text:
Bayesian statistics is to inference and decision theory what 
Laplacian Determinism is to physics and engineering.https://twitter.com/VladZamfir/status/1047217122366111744 …

1040966462054260736.text: Meanwhile, @Uber is setting up in #Toronto to expand AI research. But will they contribute to improving the city itself? I hope so, but I fear work on self-driving cars will be an excuse to not do so, to sacrifice quality for "efficiency" once again.

1040966460930174976.text: Seems to me the much more responsible and #antifragile thing to do is build more walkable cities. Reduce the need for cars all together! Thankfully, there are strong voices like @jen_keesmaat pushing cities in this direction.

1040966459508305920.text: And unlike space software, we don't even know how AI works. It's mostly a black box carved from the mysterious belly of large scale gradient descent. How can we even begin to talk about safe software for navigating cities when we don't even understand how the software works?

1040966458367504386.text: But the essence of a city is its vagaries, its dynamic condition, its chaotic constituency, and the interminable presence of adversaries! A city is a stampede of millions of unpredictable humans doing strange and unimaginable things. There are no deterministic equations.

1040966456907898880.text: In space we understand the model. We understand the equations. We can practically enumerate all the variables. We have no adversary. We can write safe, predictable, deterministic software that will reliably put us on the moon.

1040966455787970561.text: Not to mention attacks on AI engines themselves. We've only just begun to think about building "safe" AI software - a very different ordeal from "safe" physics software, like for space programs.

897191301048926208.text: And so self-sufficient cities are critical to a sustainable global society

897190954582642693.text: But the city is the new atomic unit of global economics

897190692090507264.text: ultimately this may be how we peacefully decentralize federal power. I don't want cities to go to war with their countries

897190519331336193.text: community coin backed by municipal coin backed by provincial coin backed by federal coin

897190441103368192.text: Additionally, @BancorNetwork may provide very interesting approach for coupling to exist systems

897190270428753921.text: But needs to be grounded in real economic issues and values - local food prod & dist, child & elder care; education; art; shelter; etc.

897189948696219649.text: But riding on those, I hope we can start to deploy strictly local systems to address systemic poverty

897189785575596032.text: Currently @tendermint_team seems to have the most applicable tech for this, and @cosmos_hq is first public scale deployment

897189292136681487.text: The real impact of this tech will be on transparent and accountable local economic systems that reward valuable contributions to community

897188996673142784.text: This is what got me so interested in the #blockchain space. Global anonymous crypto-anarchy is awesome. But its mostly a hedge for the rich

897188876141375489.text: "Sustainability" as ppl describe it is fundamentally incompatible with debt-based finance

897188694326730752.text: But w/ local economics and self-sufficiency, its a diff game. Debt-backed money provides access to larger markets, but not needed for life

897188454102163456.text: If you have to get access to a debt-backed currency to achieve basic sustenance, you're doomed to a life of poverty

897188296354385920.text: The key to the fix are local economic systems - free from globally entrenched debt based economies

897188226670231552.text: The last ~100y of urban & financial engineering has been completely at odds with attaining this. But those systems are bursting at the seems

897187800826642433.text: I suspect we can stitch a more robust capitalist society together out of small communist pieces: families, neighbourhoods, communities

897187548379918338.text: Communism works on a very small scale: in your family, on the kibbutz; group sizes below dunbar's number

897187375604015107.text: I think this is the missing middle ground between communism and capitalism, if you like. A 3rd economic model we seem to have missed
